title: Improving health benefits with considering traditional and modern health benefits of Peganum harmala - Clinical Phytoscience
author: Shahrajabian; Mohamad Hesam; Sun; Wenli; Cheng; Qi
description: Background Medicinal plants are potential source of natural products that play an important role in preventing different human diseases. P. harmala is used traditionally as emmenagogue and an abortifacient agent in the Middle East, North of Africa and West of China. It belongs to the family of Zygophyllaceae and it is a wild growing flowering plant. Its seeds are main medicinal part of the plant. Methods The current searching was done by the keywords in main indexing systems including PubMed/MEDLINE, Scopus, and Institute for Scientific Information Web of Science as well as the search engine of Google Scholar. The keywords were wild rue, traditional medicine, Harman, health benefits, and pharmaceutical science. Results The most important uses of P. harmala in traditional pharmaceutical sciences are in cardiovascular, gasterointestinal, nervous, endocrine, neoplasm and tumors, pain relieving, organisms, diabetes, respiratory, disinfectant, anti-pyretic, skin and hair, rheumatism, arthritis and inflammation, and ulcers. Pharmacological effects of P. harmala are in cardiovascular system, nervous system, antimicrobial effects, antineoplasm, nervous system, endocrine, gastrointestinal effects, osteocytes, endocrine and respiratory system. Phenolic compounds are the main reason of antioxidant capacity. Conclusions Due to its pharmacological activities, P. harmala is a high potential medicinal herb and the suggestion is to increases by doing research in efficacy and safety.

Background Wild rue (P. harmala) occurrence and classification Medicinal plants have been used for many years as remedies for both human and animal ailments [ [1](#ref-CR1), [2](#ref-CR2), [3](#ref-CR3), [4](#ref-CR4), [5](/articles/10.1186/s40816-021-00255-7#ref-CR5)]. Aromatic and medicinal plants as the key source of complementary and alternative medicine have been recently bring many hopes in alleviating of symptomatology and curing associated with so many diseases [ [6](#ref-CR6), [7](#ref-CR7), [8](#ref-CR8), [9](/articles/10.1186/s40816-021-00255-7#ref-CR9)]. P. harmala, commonly called Esfand, Wild rue, Syrian rue, African rue, is a plant of the family Nitrariaceae [ [10](/articles/10.1186/s40816-021-00255-7#ref-CR10)]. This plant is native from the eastern Iranian region west to India [ [11](/articles/10.1186/s40816-021-00255-7#ref-CR11)]. P. harmala is a traditional medicinal plant which is used for many purposes, the aim of this review is to survey on some health benefits of this traditional medicinal plant. Scientific classification of harmal is shown in Table [1](/articles/10.1186/s40816-021-00255-7#Tab1). It is considered as one of the most important medicinal plant in Iranian traditional medicine, which has various benefits such as anti infection, anti inflammation, anti tumor and anti parasite. This important multipurpose medicinal plant has many phytochemical features, and contains a number of active alkaloids, particularly beta-carbolines such as harmalol, harmaline, and harmine. The plant is perennial which can grow to approximate 0.8 m tall, and the root can reach a depth of up to 6 m [ [12](/articles/10.1186/s40816-021-00255-7#ref-CR12)]. This perennial herbaceous plant, branched into 5-13 stems, the leaves are palmatisected into 3-5 linear lobes which are 3-6 cms long and 1.5-3.0 mm wide. Flowers arise by 1-3 on apexes of branches which bear whitish-yellow petals in color, and the fruits are globular capsule with 3 chambers, 0.9-1.3 cm in diameter and containing 35-45 angular blackish seeds. Various parts of P. harmala (a) Leaves and Flowers, (b) Fruit, (c) Seeds are shown in Fig. [1](/articles/10.1186/s40816-021-00255-7#Fig1). P. harmala Nutritional Composition and Chemical Constituents The fruits digestive, hallucinogenic, diuretic, antipyretic, [ [13](/articles/10.1186/s40816-021-00255-7#ref-CR13), [14](/articles/10.1186/s40816-021-00255-7#ref-CR14)]. The leaves used in the treatment of asthma, colic, dysmenorrhea, hiccups, neuralgia, hysteria and rheumatism [ [15](/articles/10.1186/s40816-021-00255-7#ref-CR15)]. Harmine was originally isolated from seeds of P. harmala in 1847 having a core indole structure and a pyridine ring [ [16](/articles/10.1186/s40816-021-00255-7#ref-CR16)]. Faskhutdinov et al. [ [17](/articles/10.1186/s40816-021-00255-7#ref-CR17)] isolated two alkaloids, 7-O-(2-O-rhamnosyl-2-O-glucosylglucoside), and the glycoflavone 2-O-rhanmosyl-2-O-glucosylcytisoside were found in the aerial parts of P. harmala [ [18](/articles/10.1186/s40816-021-00255-7#ref-CR18)]. Massoud et al. [ [19](/articles/10.1186/s40816-021-00255-7#ref-CR19)] expressed that present are harmaline, harmine, harmalol, and peganine. Lamchouri et al. [ [20](/articles/10.1186/s40816-021-00255-7#ref-CR20)] also indicated that harmaline, the active principle of the seeds of P. harmala and its derivatives cause visual troubles, agitation, delirium, loss of coordination and it can produce paralysis at high doses. They found three major quinazoline alkaloids, namely, peganine which appeared in flowers and leaves in high levels, high amounts of deoxypeganine and peganine which found in immature and green fruits, and high amounts of deoxypeganine and peganine which discovered in immature and green fruits, and also peganine and peganine glycoside accumulated in high amount in dry seeds, while roots and stems contained low amount of quinazolines. Phytochemicals detected in the crude extracts of P. are terpenoids and P. harmala H-NMR [40](/articles/10.1186/s40816-021-00255-7#ref-CR40)]. Medicinal Uses and Potential Health Benefits in Traditional Medicine and Modern Medicine Industry The most important therapeutic effects of P. harmala potential, and pesticide effects [ [41](/articles/10.1186/s40816-021-00255-7#ref-CR41), [42](/articles/10.1186/s40816-021-00255-7#ref-CR42)]. The most important traditional uses of P. harmala are cardiovascular, gasterointestinal, nervous, endocrine, neoplasm and tumors, pain relieving, diabetes, respiratory diseases, disinfectant, anti-pyretic, skin and hair, ulcers, rheumatism, arthritis and inflammation [ [43](/articles/10.1186/s40816-021-00255-7#ref-CR43), [44](/articles/10.1186/s40816-021-00255-7#ref-CR44)]. Wang et al. [ [44](/articles/10.1186/s40816-021-00255-7#ref-CR44)] reported P. harmala as a traditional Chinese and Uygur medicine to treat cancer. They have found Osteoarthritis (OA) as a promising leading compound for the development of an anti-lung cancer drug. Mamedov et al. [ [39](/articles/10.1186/s40816-021-00255-7#ref-CR39)] found that Syrian rue used for centuries in traditional medicine and shows a potential treatment of anxiety and depression. Abolhassanzadeh et al. [ [45](/articles/10.1186/s40816-021-00255-7#ref-CR45)] demonstrated that topical application of Peganum oil for knee osteoarthritis is an effective pain-reducing treatment. Shatarat et al. [ [46](/articles/10.1186/s40816-021-00255-7#ref-CR46)] indicated that the root extract of P. harmala possesses antispasmodic activity and justifies its use traditionally in alleviating gastrointestinal disorders. In most parts of Iran, dried capsules mixed with other ingredients are burnt to produce scented smoke that is used to purify the air and the mind and it is also used as a charm against the evil eye [ [47](/articles/10.1186/s40816-021-00255-7#ref-CR47)]. The most popular activities of P. harmala in traditional Iranian medicines are analgesic, intoxicating, abortive, disinfectant, anthelmintic, insect repellant, carminative and its beneficial effect in colic disorder [ [48](/articles/10.1186/s40816-021-00255-7#ref-CR48)]. Shahverdi et al. [ [49](/articles/10.1186/s40816-021-00255-7#ref-CR49)] described that P. harmala seeds, smoke is traditionally used in Iran as both a disinfectant agent and for all kinds of rituals against evil eye and bad luck. They have reported the antimicrobial activity of dichloromethane condensate prepared from P. harmala seeds (Esphand). Lamchouri and discovered that P. harmala alkaloid inhibited the growth of four tumor cell lines, and proliferation of Jurkat cells with varying potencies, harmine was the most potent in inhibiting cell growth, and vasicinone was the most active as anti-proliferation substance. The analgesic, anti-inflammatory [ [51](/articles/10.1186/s40816-021-00255-7#ref-CR51)], disinfectant [ [52](/articles/10.1186/s40816-021-00255-7#ref-CR52)], growth promoting [ [53](/articles/10.1186/s40816-021-00255-7#ref-CR53)], cholesterol lowering and hepato protective effects [ [54](/articles/10.1186/s40816-021-00255-7#ref-CR54)] have been reported. Eini et al. [ [55](/articles/10.1186/s40816-021-00255-7#ref-CR55)] concluded that methanolic extract of P. harmala could be effectively used in rat to optimize serum lipid profile. Rahimi-Moghaddam et al. [ [56](/articles/10.1186/s40816-021-00255-7#ref-CR56)] showed P. harmala extract showed significant in vitro and in vivo antileishmanial activities. Ataee et al. [ [25](/articles/10.1186/s40816-021-00255-7#ref-CR25)] discovered that drinking a glass of boiled Esfand seeds may reduce blood sugar, and complaining of nausea, general weakness, abdominal pain, dizziness and several vomiting episodes. High dose of Esfand can reduce spermatogenesis in mice [ [57](/articles/10.1186/s40816-021-00255-7#ref-CR57)]. Aboualigalehdari et al. [ [58](/articles/10.1186/s40816-021-00255-7#ref-CR58)] revealed that P. harmala as antibiofilm herbal medicine for C. albicans, they have concluded that it seems to be necessary to investigate traditional herbs against pathogenic microorganisms. It has been reported that the seeds contain a red pigment used for coloring wool and carpets and also use as a spice as important aphrodisiac in traditional medicine [ [39](/articles/10.1186/s40816-021-00255-7#ref-CR39)]. Ismahane et al. [ [59](/articles/10.1186/s40816-021-00255-7#ref-CR59)] indicated that P. harmala essential oils have an ovicidal, adulticidal and larvicidal effects against Ectomyelois ceratoniae and it may be used as an alternative of chemical pesticides. Rezaei et al. [ [60](/articles/10.1186/s40816-021-00255-7#ref-CR60)] concluded that aqueous extract of P. harmala could prevent symptoms and reduced oxidative stress markers in rats with Parkinson induced by 6-hydroxydopamine. Singh et al. [ [61](/articles/10.1186/s40816-021-00255-7#ref-CR61)] showed that the ethanolic extract of P. harmala is as effective as metformin in reducing the blood glucose levels of normoglycemic and streptozotocin-induced diabetic rats. Darabpour et al. [ [62](/articles/10.1186/s40816-021-00255-7#ref-CR62)] noted that P. harmala can be assigned as a source of antibacterial compounds for treatment of infections caused by multi-drug resistant (MDR) bacterial pathogens. Chegeni et al. [ [63](/articles/10.1186/s40816-021-00255-7#ref-CR63)] noted that ethanolic extracts of P. harmala could be considered a new natural compound against the Acanthamoeba trophozoites and cysts. Tanweer et al. [ [64](/articles/10.1186/s40816-021-00255-7#ref-CR64)] discovered that methanolic extract of P. harmala could be effectively used in broilers to optimize serum lipid profile to decrease feeding cost and to maximize gross return. Shah and Khan [ [65](/articles/10.1186/s40816-021-00255-7#ref-CR65)] reported that P. harmala seeds are antiseptic, and used is the treatment of asthma, paralysis, gastrointestinal, urinary problems, epilepsy and also menstrual disorders. Khademalhosseini et al. [ [66](/articles/10.1186/s40816-021-00255-7#ref-CR66)] confirmed that ethanol extract of P. harmala has appropriate effect on the microorganisms and the healing of skin wounds in comparison with Betadine. Mohsenipour and Hassanshahian [ [67](/articles/10.1186/s40816-021-00255-7#ref-CR67)] suggested that P. harmala extracts applied as antimicrobial agents testing bacteria particularly in biofilm forms. Shirani-Boroujeni et al. [ [68](/articles/10.1186/s40816-021-00255-7#ref-CR68)] noted that the application of P. harmala seed can be useful in reducing urinary symptoms in patients with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). Berrougui et al. [ [69](/articles/10.1186/s40816-021-00255-7#ref-CR69)] suggested that P. harmala compounds could be a major source of compounds that inhibit low density lipoprotein (LDL) oxidative modification induced by copper. The seeds of P. harmala have been widely used for the treatment of nervous, cardiovascular, gastrointestinal, respiratory and endocrine diseases and some human aliments [ [70](/articles/10.1186/s40816-021-00255-7#ref-CR70), [71](/articles/10.1186/s40816-021-00255-7#ref-CR71)]. are capable of disrupting the permeability of the membranes of red blood cells of ruminants [ [75](/articles/10.1186/s40816-021-00255-7#ref-CR75)]. Pharmaceutical benefits of P. harmala are shown in Table [2](/articles/10.1186/s40816-021-00255-7#Tab2). The most important health benefits of P. harmala are shown in Fig. [2](/articles/10.1186/s40816-021-00255-7#Fig2). Conclusions P. harmala is a perennial herbaceous, glabrous plant mainly found in the Middle East, North Africa, and Central Asia. The plant is not usually grazed by animals due to its bitter taste. Its seeds showed that alkaloids belonging to the -carboline family such as harmine, harmaline, harman, harmol and harmalol are responsible or a wide range of pharmacological effects. The main compounds from P. harmala effect, cancer effect, hepatoprotective effect, hypoglycemic effect, antibacterial effect, pesticide effect, antitumor effect, antinociceptive effects, haemosporidian infections effect and different unknown beneficial properties. This review article suggests the important potential of P. harmala to be employed in both new western and eastern therapeutic drugs. This review article emphasizes on the need of widespread researches and studies for covering the supplementary information and knowledge on the importance of medicinal crops. This review also suggests more evidences for other researchers to use P. harmala as an ancient efficacious natural drug. Availability of data and materials Not applicable.
